isis.stitle: International® T 444E Diesel Engine Service, Model Year 1994 - 1998 - CRANKCASE, CRANKSHAFT, CONNECTING RODS AND PISTONS - Crankcase Reconditioning - Deglazing

step1.para: Remove the piston cooling jets. Refer to Piston Cooling Jets, Removal for the procedure.
Cylinder bore can be deglazed using a 120 grit glaze breaking brush. Install a 50 mm (2 in) section of rubber hose over the end of the shaft .

This silicone carbide-tipped nylon flexible brush quickly deglazes cylinder walls and produces a cross-hatch pattern on the cylinder wall surface in a single operation. The brush contours itself to the cylinder wall and conditions the wall surface without altering the cylinder bore.

figure.caption: Preparing the Glaze Breaking Brush for Deglazing

step1.para: Obtain a 355 ml (12 oz) can of PE-12 Solvent and Penetrating Fluid manufactured by AGS (or equivalent), available at any well-stocked auto supply house. This spray contains colloidal graphite and works well for this application. Spray both the cylinder to be deglazed and the glaze breaking brush.

step2.para: Attach the glaze breaking brush to a variable speed electric or air powered drill motor.
Deglaze the cylinder wall for about 15 seconds while stroking the bore up and down at a rate of one complete up and down stroke per second.
A speed of approximately 100-120 rpm is required. Speed adjustment is required for the procedure to be successful.

Withdraw the glaze breaking brush from the cylinder bore while the brush is rotating. Wipe a portion of the cylinder wall and inspect the cross-hatch pattern. Compare it to an untouched cylinder bore. The crosshatch pattern should be approximately 45°.
If the pattern is "flatter" than required, increase the up and down stroke speed or slow down the drill rotation.
Continue deglazing the cylinder bore for 10-15 seconds or 20-25 strokes.
Wipe the cylinder bore clean and inspect the bore for a proper 45° cross-hatch pattern.

step1.para: After deglazing, thoroughly clean the cylinder bores with a soft bristle brush, soap and water. Dry the bores with filtered compressed air and lubricate the bores with clean engine oil.
Install the piston cooling jets before assembly. Refer to Piston Cooling Jets, Installation for the procedure.
